scopecontent.p: Section A (14 volumes and one box w/unpublished calendar for 12 of the vols.): John Smith, a member of a Quaker family of Burlington, New Jersey, came to Philadelphia in 1743 where he soon became a successful merchant in trade with the West Indies and London. During his residence in the city, he was active in civic affairs and served in the Pennsylvania Assembly, 1750-1752. In 1756 he retired to the family residence in Burlington. John Jay Smith, grandson of John Smith, first entered into business in 1818 with Solomon Temple as a wholesale drug merchant. The partnership ended in 1821, and after some further small efforts in commercial ventures, Smith's principal activity was in the literary field. He published Pennsylvania Gazette, 1827-1829, edited Waldie's Circulating Library, 1832-1845, Horticulturist, 1855-1860, and a variety of other literary, historical, and horticultural periodicals and books. From 1829 to 1851, Smith was Librarian of the Library Company of Philadelphia. He was an organizer and treasurer of the Athenian Institute, a group which arranged a series of public lectures. In 1850, Smith led efforts to bring portions of the London Exposition of Art and Industry to the United States. He was a founder and promoter of Laurel Hill Cemetery through which he developed an interest in landscape gardening. John Jay's mother's family is also represented in the family papers, mostly in regard to the management of the Richard Hill estate property by son Henry Hill and son-in-laws Samuel Preston Moore. Henry also took over his father's wine and commission business in Madeira which he carried on with his other brothers in-law Robert Bisset and Thomas Lamar. The earliest portion of these papers consists of sermons, epistles, testimonies, and other documents relating to the Society of Friends. Correspondence to John Smith in Philadelphia, primarily from his father Richard in Burlington, concerns both business and family matters. Later correspondence to John, after his return to Burlington, comes from Philadelphia Friends, William Logan chief among them, reporting on public and family affairs. There are Samuel Preston Moore and Henry Hill deeds, survey warrants, leases, releases, etc., including copies relating to the original William Penn land grants. Late 18th-century manuscripts are letters, bills, invoices, to Henry Hill concerning Hill, Lamar, & Bisset's wine exportation from Madeira to America and London, as well as other mercantile and family business. The last section of the Smith family papers is correspondence to John Jay Smith, particularly from John Fanning Watson about historical matters; George Taylor on publishing the Pennsylvania Gazette; G. A. Shryock on paper manufacture; Dionysius Larnder on his U.S. lecture tour; A. J. Downing on horticulture, and miscellaneous correspondents concerning the London Exposition. Section B: John Smith manuscripts include accounts of personal business finances, 1743-77: wastebooks (4 v.), journal, ledgers (2 v.), invoice books--inward (2 v.); Smith's accounts with John Pole, 1763-71, and with Abel James, 1764; and other account books. John Smith's diaries, 1738-52, report primarily on meetings of the Friends, weather, and his social activities, particularly his courtship of Hannah Logan. Only occasional remarks on business and public affairs are made. Smith also made extensive notes of biographical and bibliographical information on Quaker ministers (2 v.). This section also includes Samuel Preston Moore's personal receipt books, 1758-81, as well as Pennsylvania provincial accounts, 1758-64, while he was serving as Provincial Treasurer. Henry Hill's account books, 1763-75 (2 v.), record mostly business transactions with Hill Lamar & Bisset, while his receipt books, 1788-1802 (2 v.) are mainly personal. There are College of Philadelphia accounts, 1789-91, Henry Hill, Treasurer. Deeds, leases, releases, powers of attorney and other documents relate to family property, mostly in Philadelphia and Bucks Counties. Section C: The bulk of this group of papers are of 19th century Smiths. John Jay Smith pays court to his future wife Rachel Pearsall in a series of letters, 1820-21 (40 items); letters, 1850-51 (150 items), to him concern the efforts to bring the London exposition to Philadelphia or New York. There is some incoming correspondence on miscellaneous subjects. Horace John Smith, John Jay's son, was a man with occasional careers. During the Civil War, he was a member of the U.S. Christian Commission. He was a partner in a China business through the 1860's and in the following decade he was a general manager and treasurer of West Laurel Hill Cemetery. Much of his time was spent traveling in the American West and Europe. In his later years he and his wife settled in England. His papers are highly miscellaneous and only touch on his various activities. They include: letters to his wife Margaret Longstreth Smith giving some information on his work with the Christian Commission; incoming correspondence; personal and business accounts, especially for West Laurel Hill Cemetery; memoranda; scrapbooks. Among other family manuscripts are John Smith commonplace books (3 v.); Hannah Smith diary, 1775-76, chronicling activities of NJ Society of Friends; letters of various family members touring Europe at various times; Elizabeth P. Smith notes and lessons for her Bible class, 1871-81; scattered letters of Logans and Pearsalls; poetry albums; and memorabilia.
